The questions cannot be answered solely within the document or the background knowledge. D.C. United remains an evolving enterprise under Coach Wayne Rooney, still missing pieces and still finding its way through the early stage of the MLS season. At the least, United plays hard for the former English superstar, whose fierce determination as a player in Washington a few years ago won over skeptical fans. On Saturday, for the second time in two appearances at Audi Field this season, United’s resolve produced another stirring finish — albeit this time one that yielded only one point. Midfielder Chris Durkin scored a wonderful goal in the 80th minute, ending a night of frustration for goal-averse United in a 1-1 draw with Orlando City. Opportunities were aplenty for United (1-1-1), but it took Durkin’s strike to offset rookie Duncan McGuire’s goal early in the second half. “I wanted to see a reaction [to Orlando’s goal], which I did, so 90 percent of the game I thought was good. The 10 percent, it wasn’t,” Rooney said. “We need to make sure when we go into them [low] periods, we’re harder to beat or harder to score against.” He added, “There’s a lot of positives we can take from it — just frustrating we didn’t take three points.” At the top of the box, Durkin cut the ball back on César Araújo, then ripped a 16-yard, left-footed shot with terrific technique and execution. The ball took flight and beat goalkeeper Pedro Gallese to the far side for Durkin’s third career MLS goal. “I can’t say I’ve hit that [with the left foot] in training before,” the right-footed Durkin said, smiling. United goalkeeper Tyler Miller said: “I didn’t know he had such a good left foot. It was amazing.” Aside from McGuire’s goal, United was much tighter and tidier defensively than it was against Columbus last weekend. In the attack, however, it remained inefficient with scoring opportunities, and Rooney said, “We could have easily been two or three up in the first half.” Orlando (1-0-2) played its first away match in league play after defeating the New York Red Bulls, 1-0, and drawing with FC Cincinnati, 0-0. At the moment, though, the Lions’ priority is the Concacaf Champions League. The visit to Washington fell between legs of a round-of-16 series with Mexican power Tigres. A 0-0 draw in Monterrey, Mexico, on Tuesday positioned them well for the return match in Florida on Wednesday. With that in mind, Orlando Coach Oscar Pareja made six lineup changes Saturday. Through three matches this year, the Lions had not conceded a goal. United was coming off a scoreless effort at Columbus, and for the first time, attacker Ted Ku-DiPietro, the hero on opening night, was in the lineup, replacing Nigel Robertha (illness). Center back Derrick Williams and right back Ruan, a former Orlando player, also made their first starts. United set the terms but continued to labor in the box. In the 27th minute, Christian Benteke was alone 12 yards out after settling Durkin’s cross, but with most of the net at his pleasure, he shot too close to Gallese, who made a reaction save. Seven minutes later, Gallese thwarted Ku-DiPietro’s 12-yard one-timer.

Question: What specific tournament or league did [human] participate in as a competitor?
data.actual_output:
1. The 2022 Major League Soccer season is the 27th season of Major League Soccer (MLS), the top-flight professional soccer league in the United States and Canada.

  1. is an English professional footballer who plays as an attacking midfielder and occasional forward. He is the manager of D.C. United.

  1. D.C. United is an American professional soccer team based in Washington, D.C., that competes in Major League Soccer (MLS).

  1. The team was founded in Washington, D.C., in 1995 as a charter member of MLS.[17]

  1. The club is owned by , and plays their home games at Audi Field, with capacity of 20,000.

  1. The club also maintains a satellite academy in Loudoun County, Virginia, where their reserve and academy teams play in the USL League Two and USL League One, respectively.

  1. D.C. United has won three MLS cups and five Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cups, and have qualified for the MLS playoffs in 13 seasons, more than any other team in the league.

  1. D.C. United has also qualified for the CONCACAF Champions League competition more than any other MLS club.

  1. The club's fandom is led by the `Black-and-Red Army`, the second-largest soccer supporter group in the U.S.

  1. D.C. United is the only MLS club to have qualified for the CONCACAF Champions League final three times.

  1. D.C. United has played in both the MLS All-Star Game and CONCACAF Champions League All-Star Game more than any other team in the league.

  1. D.C. United has had the most players selected for the MLS All-Star Game (16), and has had the most players selected for the U.S. national soccer team (26).

  1. The club's crest is a red star atop a white shield with a red and white stripe, and is based off the star on the D.C. flag.

  1. D.C. United's jerseys are red and white, and are based on the colors of the city flag.

  1. In 2018, D.C. United's season ticket sales topped 16,000 for the first time since 2011.

  1. D.C. United will play its home matches at Audi Field, which opened in 2018 in the Buzzard Point neighborhood of Washington, D.C.

  1. D.C. United was founded by , who played in the first two seasons of the original NASL in 1968 and 1969.

  1. D.C. United began play in the 1996 season as a charter franchise of Major League Soccer.

  1. D.C. United's first home was RFK Stadium.

  1. The team's first victory was a 3–0 rout of the Los Angeles Galaxy on April 14, 1996.

  1. D.C. United played its first season at RFK Stadium in 1996 and won the league championship in 1996 and 1997.

  1. In 1999, D.C. United was a founding member of the United Soccer League, a soccer league that ran from 1999 to 2001.

  1. In 1998, D.C. United played its first season at the newly built RFK Stadium, which was originally built for the Redskins.

  1. In 1998, the team left RFK Stadium for the final time, and moved to MCI Center, now known as Capital One Arena.

  1. In 1998, D.C. United won the U.S. Open Cup.

  1. In 2000, D.C. United won the Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup.

  1. In 2004, D.C. United won the Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup.

  1. In 2004, D.C. United played the final game at RFK Stadium.

  1. In 2005, D.C. United moved to their new soccer-specific stadium, Stadium, in the Buzzard's Point neighborhood of Washington, D.C.

  1. In 2005, Stadium was opened with a 1–0 victory over the New York Red Bulls.

  1. In 2007, D.C. United won the Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup.

  1. In 2007, D.C. United played the final game at the MCI Center, losing to the Los Angeles Galaxy.

  1. In 2008, D.C. United played the first game at the new home, Stadium.

  1. In 2010, D.C. United won the Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup.

  1. In 2010, D.C. United played the final game at Stadium in the final match of the season, a 4–1 victory over the Philadelphia Union.

  1. In 2011, D.C. United won the Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup.

  1. In 2011, D.C. United played the final game at Stadium in the final match of the season, a 2–1 victory over the New York Red Bulls.

  1. In 2012, D.C. United won the Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup, the first time a team has won the trophy three times.

  1. In 2012, D.C. United played the final game at Stadium in the final match of the season, a 1–0 victory over the Philadelphia Union.

  1. In 2013, D.C. United played the first game at Audi Field in the final match of the season, a 2–0 victory over the New York Red Bulls.

  1. In 2014, D.C. United won the Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup.

  1. In 2015, D.C. United lost the Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup Final.

  1. In 2016, D.C. United lost the Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup Final.

  1. In 2018, D.C. United won the Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup.

  1. In 2018, D.C. United played the final game at the MCI Center, losing to the Philadelphia Union.

  1. In 2019, D.C. United won the Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup.

  1. In 2020, D.C. United played the first game at Audi Field in the final match of the season, a 0–0 tie with the New York Red Bulls.

  1. In 2021, D.C. United won the Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup.

  1. In 2021, D.C. United played the final game at Stadium in the final match of the season, a 3–1 victory over the Toronto FC.

  1. In 2021, D.C. United played their first game at Audi Field.

You are given one document and one anonymized real-world entity with one or more mentions in the passage. Then we will ask your a question about this anonymized entity. The questions cannot be answered solely within the document or the background knowledge. Your task is to leverage world knowledge you have like Wikipedia or wikidata as background knowledge combined with the given document to answer the question related to the anonymized entity. Despite their small stature, garden gnomes spark big debates. Are they chintzy or classy? Lovable or loathsome? The perfect addition to a garden bed or an easy way to ruin your landscaping? No matter your opinion, there’s no denying that these little folks are conversation starters. The story of how these sometimes whimsical, sometimes comical, sometimes vulgar statues became fixtures in yards and gardens is as colorful and complex as the creatures themselves. “That’s the trouble with gnomes,” says Twigs Way, garden historian and author of “Garden Gnomes: A History.” “They come from lots of different kinds of sources.” There are plenty of little characters in mythologies from around the world — including the Egyptian god Bes, and brownies, house spirits in British and Scottish folklore — and small stone figures started appearing in Italian gardens during the Renaissance. However, according to Way, what have become known as garden gnomes in the United States and England can be traced to dwarf statues that originated in Germany’s Black Forest region around the early 19th century. They were initially carved out of wood; by the mid-19th century, they were cast in terra cotta and porcelain. They weren’t a garden fixture, though; they were hand-painted, usually about three feet tall and expensive, so they were intended to be displayed inside as pieces of art. Although those figures were often depicted in what has become their trademark red conical hats, blue shirts and boots, they didn’t strike lazy or lackadaisical poses. They were gardeners, carpenters, fishermen, even hunters. “To see pictures of gnomes with shotguns kind of took me aback,” says Way, who uncovered such images in old catalogues. Sir Charles Isham gets credit for bringing the dwarves into Britain and out into the garden, importing a number of them from Germany in the 1840s to decorate his massive rockery garden at Lamport Hall, his estate in Northamptonshire. It wasn’t the most auspicious introduction. “He was extremely eccentric,” Way says. “The fact that the first person that starts collecting them in England is a pro-socialist vegetarian teetotaler who believes dwarfs and little folk are real is not a great way to establish their legitimacy.” The next ambassador of the small statues was another oddball: Sir Frank Crisp, whose roughly 62-acre estate in Henley-on-Thames, Friar Park, was dotted with German garden gnomes and open to the public in the early 20th century. (George Harrison of the Beatles bought the property in 1970 and claimed to unearth a few of the original gnomes, which he posed with on the cover of his album “All Things Must Pass.”) Wealthy landowners began adopting the gnomes — as they were commonly called by then — as sophisticated garden accessories, thanks to Isham and Crisp. Photos of them even appeared in Britain’s arbiter of high-end style, Country Life magazine. In 1912, gnomes were featured at the Royal International Horticultural Exhibition, a forerunner of the Chelsea Flower Show, which began the following year and didn’t allow gnomes to be featured, because trendsetters of the time determined they weren’t tasteful enough. Their 15 minutes of fame with the posh crowd was almost over.
